The critical curve is represented by the red solid line, and the black cross indicates the position of the lensing galaxy. The filled blue circle represents the source position.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=jKXw4NtOXiubpEwjfs8J3jYeziVB-5IRgLdzbdqy-BzJkkrTAP95S8fPDGvL4NsLbf56dpPoUllb3bQly3Vk6v-2FjI6TtCOEjiYQNSVNiHeC5C8-EDWHRL15pSKhT785M7wgUhgxUn8Up6~wJVerhB0XymHhesIXY9iN~SWEhhOV-7UydV2F7rbLmjaMBVKjk-nRLwp99mKgNYlKYstugHs48HtxOQdA4NjF3A03wD9u6Ky6W7UUCZANhqNDYTwvC-DuJS7JutFiudOkijEwzqmnJu~RP37if2zQbji4eWDTd70fO3YxAOJMmOzov~MrmeSW~F8xfA~Vnxux9S2ZA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"An SIS lens mass model that reproduces the image configuration of the candidate MJV07417. The observed positions are the open circles, while the model-predicted positions are indicated by the crosses. The critical curve is represented by the red solid line, and the black cross indicates the position of the lensing galaxy. The filled blue circle represents the source position.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig6.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/127267459/sty3189fig6.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig6.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"127267459\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/sty3189fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&Signature=t5xH15Yq6K2Nmgfv6xA54Oq~klp1HfH-SXrzCpLWjMaRdmthnCr7cagOQnSQsf6Fyd8osUSdNm8qwSKE6kTjwn6OfBFSmcuHiZL72fSmaTJZRaV-4VY5EHkGwqS3c~sXIHYGvGNAVRSBAQInMu83w1OhoSMf7Gvjq7faHqn~m16YKnTy~UINMoYiWXYYZhK2OZBG10~DM8DvmuQxY0Zl~VFZYChPXPCXy1BExZGeV2wpHZkQt2rPY~NNH6LfAdAOUR4hCZJJGf4wJ3QFFfNCtAJHwZeIAfK09tn3L1mO9wY2e2i0vX00ghBf-RSIdJMGpBRbuAZwMuoiWeGiX1FZBQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=127267459&ar=5211079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig6.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">An SIS lens mass model that reproduces the image configuration of the candidate MJV07417. The observed positions are the open circles, while the model-predicted positions are indicated by the crosses. The critical curve is represented by the red solid line, and the black cross indicates the position of the lensing galaxy. The filled blue circle represents the source position.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267460 id=\"127267460\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>5 THE LENSING STATISTICS OF THE MJIVE-20 GRAVITATIONAL LENS SURVEY</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">From our follow-up of an initial 3\u2009640 radio sources that were detected on mas-scales during the mJIVE-20 survey, we have re-discovered two gravitational lenses that were previously found by CLASS. This gives a lensing rate of at least 1:(1820\u00a0\u00b1 1287) for our pilot lens search, where the uncertainty is based on the Poisson statistics for the number of lensed sources discovered and the total number of sources in the parent sample. However, we have one remaining lens candidate that we cannot completely rule out given the data in hand. If this candidate were to be confirmed as a genuine gravitational lens, then this will increase our lensing rate to at least 1:(1213\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0700), which is fairly typical for galaxy-scale gravitational lensing. Note that we also checked in the mJIVE-20 catalogue for any other previously known radio-loud gravitational lenses that we may have missed during our search, but there are none. An in-depth analysis of these lensing statistics is beyond the scope of this paper, particularly given the small number statistics that we currently have. Nevertheless, we qualitatively discuss here the statistical consequences of these two lensing rates.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">If we consider a source at redshift <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>s</em></sub>, the lensing probability, \u03c4(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span><sub><em>s</em></sub>), can be derived by integrating along the light path, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update2810118_math1543386591279\" content-id=\"update2810118_math1543386591279\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\n\\tau (z_s) = \\int _0^{z_s} n(z)\\, \\sigma (z) \\, \\frac{c\\, {\\rm d}t}{{\\rm d}z}\\, {\\rm d}z,\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>where <em>n</em>(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|\u2060</span>) is the number density of the potential lens population; \u03c3(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|\u2060</span>) is the area in the image plane where the source must be in order to be strongly gravitationally lensed (the lensing cross-section), which is dependent on the mass of the lens, and the redshifts of the lens and source; and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$c\\, {\\rm d}t$|</span> is the path length to the background source, which is dependent on the cosmology and the source redshift (e.g. Turner, Ostriker\u00a0&amp; Gott <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1984</a>). The total number of gravitational lenses that are found from a survey, <em>N</em><sub>t</sub>, is calculated by integrating the lensing probabilities of all sources in the parent source population, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"update2810118_math1543386866076\" content-id=\"update2810118_math1543386866076\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nN_{\\rm t} = \\int _0^{z_{\\rm max}} \\tau (z) \\, \\frac{{\\rm d}N(z_{\\rm s})}{{\\rm d}z_{\\rm s}}\\, {\\rm d}z_{\\rm s},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where d<em>N</em>(<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$z$|</span><sub>s</sub>)/d<em>z</em><sub>s</sub> is the differential number counts of the source parent population as a function of redshift. From equations\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update2810118_math1543386591279\"></span><a href=\"#update2810118_math1543386591279\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">1</a>) and (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-update2810118_math1543386866076\"></span><a href=\"#update2810118_math1543386866076\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>), it is clear that the number of possible gravitational lenses that are found is a function of the lens (mass, redshift) and source (redshift) populations. However, the actual number of gravitational lenses that are found from a survey will also have to take into account the observational selection effects of that survey, such that the actual number of gravitational lenses, <em>N<sub>a</sub></em>, that we would expect to find is given by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ3\" content-id=\"equ3\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nN_a = N_t \\times C(\\Delta \\theta , S_{A/B}) \\times B(S_{\\nu }, z_s).\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(3)</span></div>The survey selection function, <em>C</em>(\u0394\u03b8, <em>S</em><sub><em>A</em>/<em>B</em></sub>), is dependent on the selection criteria of the lensed sources that are found from the parent sample. In equation\u00a0(<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ3\"></span><a href=\"#equ3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a>), the maximum image separation, \u0394\u03b8, and the flux density ratios, <em>S</em><sub><em>A</em>/<em>B</em></sub>, of the lensed images are used, which are dependent on the angular resolution and sensitivity of the survey. A magnification bias is also introduced by the boost on the flux density that is caused by lensing. This results in sources with an intrinsic flux density below the survey limit being included in the parent population sample. This bias factor is given by <em>B</em>(<em>S</em><sub>\u03bd</sub>, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span><sub><em>s</em></sub>), and requires knowledge of the background source number density as a function of their flux density and redshift, which should also be extended below the survey flux density limit.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">For example, in the case of CLASS, a complete sample of 11\u2009685 flat-spectrum radio sources (defined as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{4.85}^{1.4} \\ge -0.5$|</span> between 1.4 and 4.85\u00a0GHz from low-resolution imaging with NVSS and GB6, respectively) with <em>S</em><sub>4.85\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 30\u00a0mJy were observed using the VLA at 8.46\u00a0GHz with an angular resolution of 170\u00a0mas and to an rms of 170\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup>. From these observations, gravitational lenses could only be confidently identified when the image separation was \u0394\u03b8 \u2265 300\u00a0mas, and when the total flux density was <em>S</em><sub>8.46\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 18.7\u00a0mJy (i.e. for at least a 10\u03c3 detection of the weakest image and for a flux ratio of <em>S</em><sub><em>A</em>/<em>B</em></sub> \u2264 10). These criteria gave a statistical parent sample of 8958 radio sources, from which 13 gravitational lenses were found. This results in a CLASS lensing rate of 1:(689\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0190) (Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Given that the sample of 3640 radio sources detected on mas-scales by mJIVE-20 will likely be core-dominated, we can use the CLASS lensing rate to estimate that, if our parent sample had the same source properties, then we would expect 5\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02 gravitational lenses within mJIVE-20.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, when we take into account the sensitivity of the mJIVE-20 survey by imposing our condition of detecting the faintest lensed image at least at the 6.5\u03c3 level, and a minimum flux ratio of 10:1, we obtain a statistical parent population of 635 radio sources with <em>S</em><sub>1.4 GHz</sub> \u2265 10.7\u00a0mJy. Note that in our lens candidate selection, we apply a larger upper limit on the flux ratio between the putative lensed images, and our two confirmed lenses fully satisfy the condition of a flux ratio larger than 10:1. This statistical parent sample gives an mJIVE-20 lensing rate of 1:(318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0225), given the detection of two confirmed gravitational lenses, which although higher, is still consistent with the CLASS lensing rate at the 1\u03c3 level, given the small number statistics (i.e. an expectation value of 1\u00a0\u00b1\u00a01 gravitational lenses within the mJIVE-20 sample when applying the CLASS lensing rate). This implies that the lensing optical depth between the mJIVE-20 and CLASS parent populations are in agreement within the uncertainties, that is, the mJIVE\u201320 sources are consistent with the power-law number counts (McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>) and the redshift distribution (mean <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c 1.2; Henstock et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Marlow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; McKean et\u00a0al., in preparation) of flat-spectrum radio sources down to <em>S</em><sub>4.85\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 5\u00a0mJy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we note that even though the mJIVE-20 lens search probes image separations of the order of tens mas due to the excellent angular resolution of the VLBI observations, this does not necessarily mean that substantially more gravitational lenses will be discovered. For example, the image separation distribution of the CLASS sample of gravitational lenses (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>) shows a turnover at \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 1\u00a0arcsec, demonstrating a paucity of gravitational lenses found with small image separations; for the nine CLASS gravitational lenses in the statistically well-defined sample, where there is only one dominant lensing galaxy, a similar distribution is found (see Chae <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). This is because the lensing cross-section of lower mass galaxies is also lower, and in fact Chae (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>) find that the image-separation distribution from CLASS is consistent with the galaxy luminosity functions derived from the SDSS or the 2dF Galaxy Redshift Survey (see also Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a> for a discussion on the image-separation distribution with respect to the halo-mass function). Moreover, the possible mas-scale lens population has been previously investigated by Wilkinson et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>) using targeted VLBI observations of a sample of 300 radio sources, which led to a null detection of lensed sources with image separations between 1.5 and 50 mas. Therefore, it is not too unexpected that the mJIVE-20 lens search has not detected any small image-separation systems with \u0394\u03b8 &lt; 0.3\u00a0arcsec, even though the data quality is sensitive to such rare gravitational lenses.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations with a much larger sample of sources detected on mas-scales with wide-field VLBI would be needed both to test whether the lensing statistics, and hence the parent population, from the mJIVE\u201320 and CLASS sources are similar, and to detect rare systems where the image separation statistics could potentially constrain models for the halo-mass function.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267468 id=\"127267468\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>6 PROSPECTS FOR FUTURE LENS SEARCHES WITH WIDE-FIELD VLBI</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our re-discovery of two gravitational lenses found during CLASS, directly from the mJIVE-20 imaging at 1.4\u00a0GHz, has provided an immediate proof of concept that wide-field surveys with VLBI arrays can efficiently find gravitationally lensed radio sources. Although these two gravitational lens systems did not go through the same follow-up procedure as the rest of our candidates (to save observing time), such observations (at 5\u00a0GHz) were carried out as part of their discovery data sets (Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Rusin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). In this section, we now discuss the prospects for future lens surveys with wide-field VLBI. Even though observations at such a high angular resolution of just a few mas are sensitive to high brightness temperature radio sources, we divide our discussion into essentially two classes of radio source; those where the background source is compact, such as from CLASS, and those that are extended, such as from the MG lens survey.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=127267470 id=\"127267470\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-1>6.1 Compact lensed radio sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">These sources are core-dominated in morphology and have a flat or rising spectrum at cm-wavelengths due to synchrotron self-absorption. Being intrinsically compact, they are easily identifiable at mas-scales with VLBI, even when the <em>uv</em>-coverage is sparse, such as in the case of a snapshot survey. For example, all of the gravitational lenses within CLASS would be immediately recovered from a wide-field VLBI survey that has a similar sensitivity (central \u03c3<sub>rms</sub>\u00a0= 150\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup>) and <em>uv</em>-coverage (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) to mJIVE-20. However, multifrequency follow-up with VLBI would still be needed to ensure that the surface brightness and the radio spectra of the candidate lensed images are consistent with gravitational lensing. Therefore, some filtering or pre-selection of objects that have a higher likelihood of being lensed would reduce the number of false-positives and limit the amount of follow-up imaging required.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Efficiently selecting such sources, without spectral information, could be done by comparing their low-resolution flux-density at arcsec-scales with the flux-density recovered at mas-scales with a long baseline component of the observing array. For example, in the cases of MJV03238 (CLASS\u00a0B1127+385) and MJV02639 (CLASS\u00a0B2319+051), the FIRST and mJIVE-20 flux densities agree to within 10\u00a0per\u2009cent. However, compact radio sources are also sometimes highly variable. In the case of CLASS\u00a0B1127+385, radio monitoring has shown that it is not variable at 8.46\u00a0GHz (Rumbaugh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Also, although CLASS\u00a0B2319+051 has not been extensively monitored with the VLA for variability, monitoring with the Westerbork Synthesis Radio Telescope (WSRT) at 5\u00a0GHz, where the lensed images were not resolved, did not detect any rapid-variability in the total flux-density of the system within the measurement uncertainties (G\u00fcrkan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). We note that as well as the mJIVE-20 flux density being consistent with FIRST (and previous VLA imaging by Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a> and Rusin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>), the flux ratio between the two lensed images has also not changed in both systems, which also adds to the case that these objects are not variable. Therefore, if only those candidates where the mas- and arcsec-scale flux densities agree to within 90\u00a0per\u2009cent were selected as part of our search, then our initial sample of fourteen objects would have been reduced to just five candidates for follow-up imaging (including at least two confirmed gravitational lenses). As such, comparing the flux-densities on different angular-scales should help identify core-dominated radio sources and improve the efficiency of any lens search, even in the absence of spectral information.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Another method of pre-selecting VLBI-detected radio sources with a high lensing likelihood is by comparing their very precise radio positions (sub-mas) with optical information. In the vast majority of non-lensed objects, the core-dominated radio emission will be associated with AGN activity that is coincident with the centre of a massive elliptical galaxy. In the case of a gravitationally lensed radio source, with a maximum image separation of 0.5\u20132 arcsec, the radio components will be offset from the position of the lensing galaxy, by around 0.3\u20131 arcsec (depending on the particular image configuration). Such offsets would be detectable in comparison with optical imaging, which has a typical astrometric uncertainty of &lt;0.3\u00a0arcsec. This method was first suggested by Jackson\u00a0&amp; Browne (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), who compared the astrometric positions of objects within FIRST and SDSS. However, they found no new gravitational lenses as part of a small pilot search with the VLA and MERLIN, mainly due to the positional uncertainties of the respective surveys being too large. Future optical surveys, such as with the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope, will have a better astrometric precision, particularly when referenced to <em>Gaia</em>, which will allow for a better pre-selection of likely lensed objects for high-resolution follow-up.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">The expected number of compact radio sources that are gravitationally lensed can be estimated using the CLASS lensing rate and assuming that the redshift distribution and number counts of the background source population do not change significantly at low flux densities. There is evidence that the composition of the compact radio source population is changing from being dominated by quasars to radio galaxies towards lower flux densities, but the overall mean redshift down to <em>S</em><sub>4.85\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 5\u00a0mJy seems to be fairly consistent at <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$z$|</span> \u223c 1.2 (Henstock et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Marlow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; McKean et al. in preparation). In addition, our lens search using the mJIVE-20 survey data is consistent with their being no change in the properties of the parent population. The differential number counts of flat-spectrum radio sources with flux densities <em>S</em><sub>4.85\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 5\u00a0mJy are well described by the power law, <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ4\" content-id=\"equ4\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{eqnarray*}\r\nn(S) = (6.91\\pm 0.42) \\left(\\frac{S_{4.85}}{100~{\\rm mJy}} \\right)^{-2.06\\pm 0.01}~{\\rm mJy^{-1}~sr^{-1}},\r\n\\end{eqnarray*} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(4)</span></div>which can be used to estimate the number of compact radio sources that would be detectable at 1.4\u00a0GHz with the VLBA (assuming that all of the flux is recovered on mas scales, and by taking into account a median spectral index of faint flat-spectrum radio sources of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{1.4}^{4.85} = -0.15$|\u2060</span>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007a</a>). An all-sky survey at declinations \u03b4 &gt; \u221230\u00a0deg (9.42\u00a0sr area) with a 6.5\u03c3 point-source sensitivity of <em>S</em><sub>1.4\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 0.91\u00a0mJy (corresponding to a rms at the centre of the primary beam of \u03c3<sub>rms</sub>\u00a0= 140\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup>) is expected to detect 1.15\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>6</sup> radio sources on VLBI scales. From the CLASS lensing rate, it is predicted that 1675 of these radio sources will be gravitationally lensed.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">As discussed above, to identify such a sample of gravitationally lensed radio sources would require detecting at least two of the lensed images directly in the survey data. Therefore, assuming a maximum flux ratio of 10:1 between the two lensed images gives a minimum total flux density of <em>S</em><sub>1.4\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 10.0\u00a0mJy for a 6.5\u03c3 detection threshold and a central rms of \u03c3<sub>rms</sub>\u00a0= 140\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup>. This would result in a potential parent sample of 9.1\u00a0\u00d7\u00a010<sup>4</sup> radio sources, which, given the CLASS lensing rate, should provide a sample of 130 gravitational lenses (including the 22 found as part of CLASS). However, this would be for a statistically complete sample. If the flux ratio limit were relaxed (to around &lt;2:1; typical for doubly imaged sources and the merging images of quadruply imaged sources) and the survey limit was correspondingly lowered to <em>S</em><sub>1.4\u00a0GHz</sub> \u2265 2.7\u00a0mJy, then around 530 gravitational lenses could be found, potentially increasing the number of known radio-loud lensed sources by over an order of magnitude. Such a survey, in terms of depth and area, would be feasible with the VLBA at 1.4\u00a0GHz in around 3000\u00a0h (assuming 90\u00a0s on-source per pointing and a recording rate of 4096\u00a0Mbit\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>). We note that taking the primary beam attenuation into account would increase the detection threshold in those regions away from the pointing centre by at most a factor of 2, and therefore, the number of radio sources and gravitational lenses found from such a survey could decrease by at most a factor of 2 from those estimated here.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Such a sample of 530 gravitationally lensed radio-loud AGN would be useful for investigating the halo-mass function at the low-mass end, given the small image separations that could be probed (e.g. Chae <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Oguri <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>), but also for testing different models for dark matter by searching for low-mass sub-structure or sub-haloes along the line of sight (e.g. Dalal\u00a0&amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Again, assuming a similar lensing rate and ratio of doubly- to quadruply-imaged sources (about 2:1) to CLASS, around 175 new four-image lens systems are expected from the wide-field snapshot VLBI survey described above. This is close to the around 10<sup>2</sup> systems needed in order to discriminate between cold and warm dark matter models (Gilman et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Finally, the sensitivity to lensed images with extremely small separations (&gt;5\u00a0mas), would also uniquely constrain the abundance of compact objects (e.g. free-floating black holes with masses &gt;10<sup>6</sup>\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>) in the Universe (Wilkinson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Of course, if the number of lensed radio sources within the statistically complete sample differs significantly from what is predicted, then that would suggest the compact radio source population with intrinsic de-magnified flux densities of 0.2\u20130.5 mJy has likely also changed significantly in comparison to those sources that were probed by CLASS.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=127267477 id=\"127267477\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6-2>6.2 Extended lensed radio sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Sources with extended emission, such as those that produce gravitational arcs or rings at radio wavelengths (Biggs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Spingola et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>) can provide a wealth of information to determine precise mass models for the lens (Wucknitz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>). Also, due to the excellent angular resolution provided by VLBI, such lensed sources are sensitive to the direct detection of low-mass sub-structure in the lens (Vegetti et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) or along the line of sight (Despali et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), through the local change they produce in the surface brightness distribution of the extended jet-emission (Metcalf <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). However, the lensing rate of such objects is not well known, as the MG lens survey only discovered six gravitational lenses, and the survey was not designed to be statistically complete. Also, the radio sources that have produced the largest gravitational arcs are also the most luminous known, and so, new surveys that extend to fainter flux-densities will likely only detect lensed radio sources with weak jets.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Identifying those lensed radio sources with extended emission would be challenging from a snapshot survey as the <em>uv</em>-coverage would not be sufficient to detect the full extent of the gravitational arc. However, once a gravitationally lensed radio source has been identified from the survey data, an indication for extended emission that wasn\u2019t fully detected from the snapshot observations could come from comparing the total flux density measured on arcsec-scales with that found on VLBI-scales; this method can be confidently used only in the case of quadruply-imaged radio sources, because the VLBI observations alone can already show that the source is gravitationally lensed. Such objects could then be prioritized for deeper, long-track imaging in order to recover the extended gravitational arcs. However, for those cases of doubly-imaged sources with extended emission, this method would likely not be sufficient to distinguish between a lensed radio source with extended emission and a resolved non-lensed core-jet radio source, for example. Therefore, multiwavelength and spectroscopic observations would still be required to understand if such an object is gravitationally lensed or not.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267480 id=\"127267480\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec7>7 CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We have carried out the first wide-field VLBI search for gravitationally lensed radio sources using data from the mJIVE-20 survey. Among the mJIVE-20 sample of 3640 compact radio sources, 81 sources were identified as having multiple radio components that are separated by more than 100 mas and with a flux-density ratio of less than 15:1. Among them, we selected fourteen sources as gravitational lens candidates, based on the morphology and surface brightness of the radio emission at 1.4\u00a0GHz. Two of these selected candidates are a re-discovery of the known gravitational lenses CLASS\u00a0B1127+385 and CLASS\u00a0B2319+051, which provides an immediate proof of concept that this selection method is able to find lensed radio sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We have followed up the remaining 12 lens candidates at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz with the VLBA, following a strategy that is similar to the CLASS survey. Two of the targets (MJV00019 and MJV07417) have a surface brightness and spectral indices that are either consistent with lensing, or the data in hand are insufficient to rule out the lensing hypothesis; the remaining ten objects are likely core-jet radio sources. We find that in the case of MJV00019, it is not possible to reproduce the morphology of the candidate lensed images with a simple lensing mass model. For the other target, the configuration of the candidate lensed images is found to be compatible with the lensing scenario. However, since MJV07417 is detected only at 1.4\u00a0GHz, further deeper observations at 5\u00a0GHz are needed in order to confirm the true nature of this system.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on our search, we find a lensing rate for VLBI-detected radio sources at 1.4\u00a0GHz of 1:(318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0225), which although is almost a factor of 2 higher than that of CLASS, is still consistent given the large uncertainties due to the small number statistics. The implication of this result is that the lensing optical depth of compact radio sources has not changed significantly towards lower flux densities. We estimate that a wide-field survey carried out with the VLBA, to a sensitivity of 140\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup> over 9.42\u00a0sr, should find around 530 new gravitationally lensed radio sources, given the lensing-rate and source properties of the CLASS survey. Such a survey would be a precursor to what could be done with the SKA, where the \u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup> sensitivity should detect thousands of radio-loud lensed AGN (McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), which could be done most efficiently if the SKA has a VLBI component (Paragi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Finally, we note that we have looked through only part of the mJIVE-20 survey data, and now that the survey is complete, we may find new gravitationally lensed radio sources in the final 30\u00a0per\u2009cent of the data. Our search will also be refined using the results found here. In addition, we have only searched for gravitationally lensed objects with image separations \u2265100\u00a0mas. Extending the parameter space to smaller image-separations may uncover close merging pairs of quadruply imaged sources, and also potentially detect the &gt;5\u00a0mas image splitting by low mass, compact objects along the line of sight to the distant radio sources.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267485 id=\"127267485\" class=\"backacknowledgements-title\" >ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The authors thank the referee Olaf Wucknitz for the careful reading of the manuscript and useful comments, which improved the presentation of this work. CS would like to thank L.\u00a0V.\u00a0E. Koopmans for useful discussions and comments on this paper. This work is supported in part by NWO grant 629.001.023. ML acknowledges support from the ASTRON/JIVE summer student programme. The National Radio Astronomy Observatory is a facility of the National Science Foundation operated under cooperative agreement by Associated Universities, Inc. This work made use of the Swinburne University of Technology software correlator, developed as part of the Australian Major National Research Facilities Programme and operated under licence.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267487 id=\"127267487\" class=\"backfootnotegroup-title\" >Footnotes</h2>\r\n<div content-id=\"fn1\"><span class=\"fn\"><span class=\"label fn-label\"><span rel=\"nofollow\" data-fn-id=\"fn1\" class=\"end-note-link\">1</span></span><div class=\"footnote-content\"><p class=\"footnote-compatibility\"><a class=\"link link-uri openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://safe.nrao.edu/vlba/mjivs/products.html\" target=\"_blank\">http://safe.nrao.edu/vlba/mjivs/products.html</a></p></div></span></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267489 id=\"127267489\" class=\"backreferences-title\" >REFERENCES</h2>\r\n<div class=\"ref-list\"><div content-id=\"bib1\" data-legacy-id=\"bib1\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib1\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib1\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref false\"><div id=\"ref-auto-bib1\" class=\"ref-content \"><div class=\"mixed-citation citation\"><p class=\"mixed-citation-compatibility\"><span class=\"person-group\"><span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Abazajian</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">K. D.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Browne</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">I. W. A.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Muxlow</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">T. W. B.</div></span>, <span class=\"name string-name\"><div class=\"surname\">Wilkinson</div>  <div class=\"given-names\">P. class=\"citation-links\"></div><div class=\"citation-links\"><div class=\"crossref-doi js-ref-link\"><a class=\"openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/j.1365-2966.2007.11718.x\" </span></div>\u00a0</div></div></div></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=127267491 id=\"127267491\" class=\"appendix-title\" data-legacy-id=sec8>APPENDIX A: SUPPLEMENTARY FIGURES AND TABLE</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This appendix includes the maps from the 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz follow-up observations (Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a> to\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa13\" data-open=\"figa13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A13</a>), and the radio spectral energy distributions (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a>) and the flux ratios (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>) of the lens candidates. Optical images of the field around each target are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"127267493\" scrollto-destination=\"127267493\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa1\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa1.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=vdfqiY2agLzkBmfSeSG9mcYPVhrgAJoyZDLaGSNSPevSefUasqMueKK07Wp65y3kNXqjkqyrxFFi21q7D~1tMW1tXWTYCCnS4njYtBY1UewmSWrqpFndEbeqz-81S1YYvtnwGQrv~U6g6Nh7-NN5~k66D4cj99Wgnyeqs-TihA0PoiXXSB-PK~klqnJQf~37yQMFx621Il78Yyj27e-AJ4DipwNsv4CFrnrLtKMmet24xo~qj7cFBduZN7FLbJh8OBYYJTB2m95LPpoG9yTPjwesEaROAGmg60dS9suG7I50xLhFrbjhlXKvnxsYSWZDSNhth1OyrYWWAVJpHm1DCA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multifrequency images of the lens candidate MJV00019 at 1.4 (left), 4.1 (centre), and 7.1\u00a0GHz (right). The cutouts are centred at the coordinates listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"127267496\" scrollto-destination=\"127267496\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa4.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=s4Q9m~cWNO-hf1uotOs-K~AyyAOMpaNYmBoCskhvhkDUEt3GEKpwLJxeAvWcxKgPBnt~gAiHW4BjXvj4sKvK6tndbSI~jdTy1s4qjM-pKEIh0OAOFNfHATdOhYGC~q3NH5QxyUUqGxvnR9VCewMsHTgWTYbqUCYGEO5-OJ977ejKbgmkb-5GVkvyk7HKbfs4Un~KIQ4ZALg6-mkmWy5~K-rJHQA5raJnTBvKZKmwoXVl9rJAhWAf6dp~3QWr1SigKbMMnkElfEmO2TpcV-M0SFxUeboxDlXKYC2CNtADRVcSiGwfkfeZjYl0wZ9IWV1RSanBZL-0P8-PBW3JoAfH5w__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multifrequency images of the lens candidate MJV04363 at 1.4 (left), 4.1 (centre), and 7.1\u00a0GHz (right). The cutouts are centred at the coordinates listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"127267499\" scrollto-destination=\"127267499\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa7.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=XQSb3j8OKE29JvpWRWx0BwCGBQIZqaCe5tBWs1Yn0Y2ZTi3ig6BP3f6YdvSp0~vvdc12C1Gk5623YXONV5MlRTD2hAU2akw206saIhccrEYf~9r9ZrXIdFPqQ2TN4gmfKZvIzjCVt-crgz~4ba4v6Dg0cCEWTFetwSkuf3qSIX1ZrCihjCOIEteDkTQQ6zbc5ahmQLzJk0r1FWGA-G-T-iNVdYdQXEZxH-aLqWmasSK2yXDWyBtBXk2mLXWF2FjJYh-ICsGLeDNogo-6gzPyoPgBEmp38RMwPg0ESCvedx-NPrccnEviuOz3v-8vXdDLqo4YQm5pCLr2cSJHBhhmJQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multifrequency images of the lens candidate MJV07417 at 1.4 (left), 4.1 (centre), and 7.1\u00a0GHz (right). The cutouts are centred at the coordinates listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"127267502\" scrollto-destination=\"127267502\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa10\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A10.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa10.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=XU6o29isdfIkV3Vq6yw98y3ovVq1SiOiW53YR11L6u42ql2~VLyfJxVn6mKwYRGyl0PQlRJzV0iYLeNZUltIbln22SCh0qeM-VPXuhwut5p-Jlln2LnQuhrCQalBEX-eBJDQENVIT6VOZnR0NzW6AW0otv13kQmNHmDEwMpl01xuesxi8QhaKGBMF9KJg~7OnlzDiaB0IW1l9YAA8mhEkZuY35pgq4Bys~2MwyaumCfc~h0fiW3fZAJAOxeiIjpXDzm5eb7Mq9usfSUDektWiZcZk6TdhP0z4Xf-BsTDoVFNwTkdfcu6~uu-sCFvKUKSl6xXMkMSd68PDujw1OnXVQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multifrequency images of the lens candidate MJV11797 at 1.4 (left), 4.1 (centre), and 7.1\u00a0GHz (right). Component A is shown on the top row, and component B is shown on the bottom row. The beam is plotted in red on the bottom left corner of each image. Contour levels increase by a factor of 3, where the first contour is three\u00a0times the off-source noise level and the cutouts are 0.08 arcsec\u00a0\u00d7 0.08 arcsec. The cutouts are centred at the coordinates listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"127267505\" scrollto-destination=\"127267505\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa13\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A13.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa13.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=o9Oi2KhS0e2pHF1a9nhxZru6x7d-RIz4mzIgmys1ao3SNK8BzHbktyBljx6617cyhvRceXACyLBLFLAJowBM~v5x-hR7a4rtv9ESFYj-oTPlzCOlg9tl9gqR3F7Z8tExPc~u7O3~BzVhs9NeZXKeQoffOTJ7Oand2W5ZtmwgxaHSzZvT33dgOnFzYj-cVdUsBkGGCbjCHGENnkl6jMCPcqmWl-9~bZQrjVQdO8NazuSv0iCiPrE0Mg3iBJs7xWOj2ZTVYc6OdW2b4AFfTPr3SDMMUd5JPw5HStcScc~9rZrGUZc0PKTCqXUi7H6GLVMAxurtpNIV0phZt8vzx8DWbQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Multifrequency images of the lens candidate MJV16999 at 1.4 (left), 4.1 (centre), and 7.1\u00a0GHz (right). The arrows indicate the 3\u03c3 detection limit at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, estimated as three times the flux density within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. The uncertainty on the flux density is assumed to be 10\u00a0per\u2009cent, which is a conservative estimate of the absolute flux density calibration of the VLBA.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"figa14\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A14.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa14a.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=psS6bbMJG68iiUCse4oxz9S-Eu3zYF39rpbnOuRYhtnPcZYmiyjzNOm5AGTcEe1HlCIoDwY6QUZkvJOxnvGEvDY~Mu3vzf56rAqFZHL0~HrKDrva82OrWIbfDRwIH94~aRtk0g0svfGWN6tCMupk1cGF6w54cmV16oo2CjLEsusofjMXHF7zLdDcvtpOJUZmIr1Tq5bsO6kJS6~TdKM1B5fCbuLhVCLKEVss2S1klOZJb3xBiYsxl1YNgVjZqGgH-3KSXozTgPM6jEyXMfKvTd1Pl1wh5YAWaogpIwYzfPpqiUQHTJWesO5rLH204iFldTuG92gTDLFS~Lp4vHY8Jg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The spectral energy distribution of the lens candidates between 1.4 and 7.1\u00a0GHz. The arrows indicate the 3\u03c3 detection limit at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, estimated as three times the flux density within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. The uncertainty on the flux density is assumed to be 10\u00a0per\u2009cent, which is a conservative estimate of the absolute flux density calibration of the VLBA.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"127267507\" scrollto-destination=\"127267507\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"figa15\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure A15.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189figa15a.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=CiluaZ9cCHYkFToU8EgJBfId-fYnHYE9wdkkzIkInWf12GIR~6sHkEFAf4~PzEAxNS-mGt0yP22O7l90fbXKGZ5yRWt-Wj0VDj7iROS4xzPmcfzgLyKBTeau7Noifq6yTV3pQztvf5aY9~osdyVEvu9kEXaq70cQZwitmM1JpFr-SMyFOcvywMDZhMoaQN9lrmg1zNG55VC5PuF3WnaJ6pVAsVnm~HuJvr8hyO5Fcds7G-nsOlkCZCJH4T5GaOr7TSbXAyw8HzSaNUgBpriTqvli2lTCaM8t1WlkZZd9kF-rqfHVhJNMT-LiWaqXP~yDR~8IpXTgXLPdqwRySHd~tg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The flux density ratio (B/A) of the lens candidates as a function of frequency. src=\"//ouptag.scholarlyiq.com/ntpagetag.gif?js=0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" border=\"0\" hspace=\"0\" vspace=\"0\" alt=\"Scholarly IQ\" />\r\n    </noscript>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"ad-banner js-ad-riser ad-banner-riser\">\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-AdBlock widget-instance-RiserAd\">\n         \n    </div>\n\r\n    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n</body>\r\n</html>\r\n\r\n", "Table captions or footers": {"Overview": " class=\"chapter-para\">This lens candidate is detected only at 1.4\u00a0GHz and, therefore, could not be ruled out through the multifrequency imaging. Since component B is unresolved, we do not have any constraints to test the parity of the candidate lensed images. Moreover, the positions of the two components do not give enough constraints to test a realistic lensing mass model. For this reason, we also use the flux density of components A and B to constrain the SIS mass model; this gives five observational constraints to a model that has five free parameters (the lensing galaxy position, its mass strength, and the position of the source). In general, the image flux density may not be reliable, either because of the possible intrinsic variability of compact radio sources (e.g. Biggs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>), because of the presence of sub-structures (in the lens plane or along the line of sight; e.g. Mao\u00a0&amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), or because of possible propagation effects due to the interstellar medium (e.g. Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Mittal et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). Therefore, we assume an uncertainty of 20\u00a0per\u2009cent on the flux density of the candidate lensed images to take into account these possible effects. Our SIS mass model that reproduces the image positions is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>. The SIS has a mass strength <em>b</em> that corresponds to half the angular separation between the two images (<em>b</em>\u00a0= 0.23\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.03) and the lensing galaxy is at (<em>x<sub>l</sub></em>, <em>y<sub>l</sub></em>)\u00a0=\u00a0(\u22120.28\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.02, 0.06\u00a0\u00b1\u00a00.04), with respect to image A. Based on lens modelling, it is not possible to rule out this candidate as a gravitational lens. However, given the simplicity of the model, in order to confirm the lensing nature, further multifrequency observations that detect both components are need. Also, deeper optical imaging may uncover the lensing galaxy or detect the AGN host galaxy if MJV07417 is not gravitationally lensed."}, "Action": "Scanned all subtables", "Status": "Complete"}, "Table Column 1: mJIVE-20 ID of the lens candidate. Column 2: name of the components. Columns 3 and 4: right ascension and declination of the component. Column 5: flux density from the FIRST survey at 1.4\u00a0GHz. The uncertainty on this flux density is around 5\u00a0per\u2009cent. Column 6: flux density from the GB6 survey at 4.85\u00a0GHz. Column 7: flux density from VLBA 1.4\u00a0GHz observations. Column 8: flux density from VLBA 4.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 9: flux density from VLBA 7.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 10: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 11: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz. Column 12: surface brightness at 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 13: surface brightness at 7.1\u00a0GHz.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>mJIVE-20 ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed properties of the final sample of 14 lens candidates. Column 1: mJIVE-20 ID of the lens candidate. Column 2: name of the components. Columns 3 and 4: right ascension and declination of the component. Column 5: flux density from the FIRST survey at 1.4\u00a0GHz. The uncertainty on this flux density is around 5\u00a0per\u2009cent. Column 6: flux density from the GB6 survey at 4.85\u00a0GHz. Column 7: flux density from VLBA 1.4\u00a0GHz observations. Column 8: flux density from VLBA 4.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 9: flux density from VLBA 7.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 10: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 11: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz. Column 12: surface brightness at 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 13: surface brightness at 7.1\u00a0GHz.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>mJIVE-20 ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n   </button>\r\n        </div>\r\n    </div>\r\n    <div class=\"content-inner-wrap\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleTopInfo widget-instance-OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    A novel search for gravitationally lensed radio sources in wide-field VLBI imaging from the mJIVE-20 survey\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                                <span class=\"al-author-name-more js-flyout-wrap\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                                    <a class=\"linked-name js-linked-name-trigger\" href=\"javascript:;\">C Spingola</a><span class='delimiter'>, </span>\r\n\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-info-wrap arrow-up\">\r\n<div id=\"authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\" class=\"info-card-author authorInfo_OUP_ArticleTop_Info_Widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"name-role-wrap\">\r\n        <div class=\"info-card-name\">\r\n    C Spingola\r\n            <span class=\"info-card-footnote\"><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-cor1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"cor1\" data-open=\"cor1\" class=\"link link-ref       });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleLinks widget-instance-OUP_Article_Links_Widget\">\n         \n
