                                 <option class=\"header-search-bar-filters-item\" value=\"Journals\" >All  Journals</option>\r\n                                    </optgroup>\r\n                            </select>\r\n\r\n                            <label for=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" class=\"screenreader-text\">search input</label>\r\n                            <input class=\"navbar-search-input microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"microsite-search-icon navbar-search-submit icon-menu_search\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search</span></a>\r\n\r\n                        </div>\r\n                    </div>                <div class=\"navbar-search-advanced\"><a href=\"/mnras/advanced-search\" class=\"advanced-search js-advanced-search\">Advanced Search</a></div>\r\n            </div>            <div class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267396 id=\"127267396\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">We present a novel pilot search for gravitational lenses in the mJIVE-20 survey, which observed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$24\\, 903$|</span> radio sources selected from Faint Images of the Radio Sky at Twenty cm (FIRST) with the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) at an angular resolution of 5\u00a0mas. We have taken the visibility data for an initial 3640 sources that were detected by the mJIVE-20 observations and re-mapped them to make wide-field images, selecting 14 sources that had multiple components separated by \u2265100\u00a0mas, with a flux ratio of \u226415:1 and a surface brightness consistent with gravitational lensing. Two of these candidates are re-discoveries of gravitational lenses found as part of the Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (CLASS). The remaining 12 candidates were then re-observed at 1.4\u00a0GHz and then simultaneously at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz with the VLBA to measure the spectral index and surface brightness of the individual components as a function of frequency. Ten were rejected as core-jet or core-hotspot(s) systems, with surface brightness distributions and/or spectral indices inconsistent with gravitational lensing, and one was rejected after lens modelling demonstrated that the candidate lensed images failed the parity test. The final lens candidate has an image configuration that is consistent with a simple lens mass model, although further observations are required to confirm the lensing nature. Given the two confirmed gravitational lenses in the mJIVE-20 sample, we find a robust lensing rate of 1:(318\u00a0\u00b1\u00a0225) for a statistical sample of 635 radio sources detected on mas-scales, which is consistent with that found for CLASS.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;gravitational lensing: strong&quot;\">gravitational lensing: strong</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: high angular resolution&quot;\">techniques: high angular resolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;techniques: interferometric&quot;\">techniques: interferometric</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: active&quot;\">galaxies: active</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;radio continuum: galaxies&quot;\">radio continuum: galaxies</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267398 id=\"127267398\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>1 INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Gravitational lensing is the deflection of light from a distant background object (the source) by a foreground mass distribution (the lens), which is typically a galaxy or cluster of galaxies (see Treu <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a> for a review). If the surface mass density of the lens is above some critical value, then multiple images of the background source can be formed. The positions and relative magnifications of these images give valuable information about the structure of the lens that can be used to investigate the lensing mass distribution and test models for galaxy formation; for example, by precisely measuring the inner mass profile of galaxy-scale dark matter haloes (e.g. Wucknitz, Biggs\u00a0&amp; Browne <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Spingola et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>), placing limits on the mass of their central supermassive black hole (e.g. Winn, Rusin\u00a0&amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Zhang et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Quinn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), constraining the properties of their interstellar medium (e.g. Mittal, Porcas\u00a0&amp; Wucknitz <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Mao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) or through determining the level of dark matter sub-structure within them (e.g. Mao\u00a0&amp; Schneider <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Brada\u010d et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Dalal\u00a0&amp; Kochanek <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Metcalf <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007b</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hsueh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). Gravitational lenses are also a powerful astrophysical tool for determining the cosmological parameters, which include precise measurements of the Hubble constant and competitive tests of dark energy (e.g. Biggs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Fassnacht et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Suyu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Biggs\u00a0&amp; Browne <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Finally, gravitational lenses magnify the high-redshift Universe, allowing detailed studies of galaxies that otherwise would not be detectable with current instruments (e.g. Barvainis\u00a0&amp; Ivison <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Impellizzeri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>; Stacey et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The examples cited above are for those cases of gravitational lensing where the background source is also radio-loud, which are at a premium for several reasons. First, the radio emission is not obscured by dust or the bright optical emission from the lens. Moreover, the source emission is also extended (generally several pc in size), and therefore, is not affected by micro-lensing from stars in the lensing galaxy; this allows any intrinsic variability of the background object to be observed or for accurate flux ratios between the different images to be measured. Furthermore, the high angular resolution imaging that is achievable with very long baseline interferometric (VLBI) observations provides precise positions for the lensed images, with an astrometric precision of tens of \u03bcas. Finally, monitoring with interferometers for time variability between the lensed images can be easily carried out.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">However, even though the first gravitational lens was found at radio wavelengths (Walsh, Carswell\u00a0&amp; Weymann <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1979</a>), and the first systematic all-sky surveys were carried out with the Very Large Array (VLA) over two decades ago (e.g. Hewitt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>; King et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Winn et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), there are only around 35 gravitational lens systems currently known where the background source is a radio-loud active galactic nucleus (AGN). When compared with the \u223c200 gravitationally lensed quasars and star-forming galaxies found with the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS; e.g. Inada et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Auger et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and the \u223c50 gravitationally lensed sub-mm galaxies found with the <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>) and the South Pole Telescope (Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), the paucity of known radio-loud gravitationally lensed objects represents a missed opportunity, particularly given the unique advantages radio data sets have over optical and sub-mm observations. In the future, surveys with the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) have the potential to discover more than 10<sup>5</sup> galaxy-scale gravitational lenses at radio wavelengths (Koopmans, Browne\u00a0&amp; Jackson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The success of these surveys will depend on improving new search strategies over the coming years.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The most successful search to date for gravitationally lensed radio sources is the Cosmic Lens All-Sky Survey (CLASS; Myers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), which found 22 gravitational lenses with a maximum image separation between 0.3 and 6 arcsec from a sample of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$11\\, 685$|</span> radio sources that were initially selected based on their flat radio-spectra at cm-wavelengths (13 gravitational lenses were found within a statistically well-defined sample of 8958 radio sources; Chae et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). The CLASS parent sample was first observed with the VLA at 8.46\u00a0GHz (\u223c170 mas resolution) and then followed-up at progressively higher angular resolution at other frequencies with the Multi-Element Radio-Linked Interferometer Network (MERLIN) and the Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) to confirm that the radio spectral energy distribution, surface brightness and polarization of the candidate multiple images were consistent with gravitational lensing. Given that the selection criteria focused on objects with a flat radio-spectrum, which are typically beamed radio sources, almost all of the lensed objects found by CLASS are unresolved or have only slightly extended jet emission when observed on VLBI-scales (e.g. Biggs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007b</a>; More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). However, the MIT-Green Bank (MG) survey (Hewitt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1988</a>), which also used the VLA to identify gravitationally lensed radio sources, targeted objects that were extended, and these have been found to have large gravitational arcs/extended images that are 100\u2013800 mas in size when observed with VLBI (More et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; MacLeod et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Spingola et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2018</a>). Therefore, both the CLASS and MG lens surveys demonstrate the potential of finding new gravitationally lensed radio sources directly from VLBI observations.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In addition, lens surveys with VLBI observations have recently become feasible with the development of wide-band receivers and higher data-recording rates that increase the imaging sensitivity, and new correlation and data processing methods that allow wide-field imaging to be carried out efficiently. Such studies have been used to investigate the relative contributions of AGN and star formation activity within radio galaxies at cosmological distances, and have typically focused on single fields that are limited by the primary beam of the individual antennas of the VLBI array (Garrett et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Wrobel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>; Garrett, Wrobel\u00a0&amp; Morganti <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Morgan et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Chi, Barthel\u00a0&amp; Garrett <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Cao et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Radcliffe et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>), but are now also being carried out over larger areas of the sky (Herrera Ruiz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2017</a>). In particular, the mJIVE\u201320 programme (mJy Imaging VLBA Exploration at 20\u00a0cm; Deller\u00a0&amp; Middelberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>) is the largest survey of the radio sky with a VLBI array, detecting 4965 radio sources in around 200\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The detectability of radio sources on VLBI-scales and the recent advances in wide-field VLBI imaging techniques can now be combined to open up a new and efficient method to increase the number of known gravitational lenses for studies of galaxy formation and cosmology. In this paper, we present the first pilot survey for such gravitational lens systems by using the large sample of sources found during the mJIVE-20 programme. Our paper is organized as follows. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec2\"></span><a href=\"#sec2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a>, we describe the steps for the selection of the lens candidates from the mJIVE-20 parent sample. Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec3\"></span><a href=\"#sec3\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">3</a> describes the high angular resolution multifrequency follow-up observations with the VLBA and the data reduction processes. We review the lensing hypothesis for the sample and discuss our results in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4\"></span><a href=\"#sec4\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4</a>. The gravitational lensing statistics of the mJIVE-20 survey and the future prospects for wide-field VLBI lens searches are discussed in Sections\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec5\"></span><a href=\"#sec5\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">5</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec6\"></span><a href=\"#sec6\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">6</a>, respectively. We summarize our conclusions in Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec7\"></span><a href=\"#sec7\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">7</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Throughout this paper, we assume <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$H_0=67.8\\,\\, \\mathrm{km\\, s^{-1}~Mpc^{-1}}$|\u2060</span>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub>\u00a0= 0.31, and \u03a9<sub>\u039b</sub>\u00a0= 0.69 (Planck Collaboration XIII, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The spectral index \u03b1 is defined as <em>S</em><sub>\u03bd</sub>\u00a0\u221d\u00a0\u03bd<sup>\u03b1</sup>, where <em>S</em><sub>\u03bd</sub> is the flux density as a function of frequency \u03bd.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267406 id=\"127267406\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>2 LENS CANDIDATE SELECTION CRITERIA</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The parent sample of our lens search has come from the mJIVE-20 survey (Project IDs: BD161 and BD170; PI: Deller), which was a 408-h VLBA filler-time project to image a large number of radio sources at 1.4\u00a0GHz with mas angular resolution (Deller\u00a0&amp; Middelberg <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This survey targeted regions of the sky with a VLBI calibrator radio source, as this allowed in-beam calibration of the antenna complex gains to be used and a more efficient use of the telescope time. A series of four sub-pointings around the calibrator radio source were used to achieve an effective field of view of 1\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> per field. The total observing time per field was 1\u00a0h, with about 15\u00a0min per sub-pointing. The data were taken using 64\u00a0MHz bandwidth and with dual polarization (a recording rate of 512 Mbit s<sup>\u22121</sup>). This observing set-up gave a close to uniform rms noise of about 150\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup> within a radius of \u223c20 arcmin around the central calibrator source when using a natural visibility weighting, while retaining a reduced sensitivity to sources out to separations of 35\u201340 arcmin. As imaging the full effective primary beam is not practical, known radio sources were first identified from the Faint Images of the Radio Sky at Twenty cm (FIRST; Becker, White\u00a0&amp; Helfand <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) survey and their positions were used as the phase centres of the multifield correlations that are provided by the DiFX software correlator (Deller et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The multifield correlations for each pointing used a spectral resolution of 1\u00a0MHz\u00a0channel<sup>\u22121</sup> and an averaging time of 3.2\u00a0s for the visibilities. However, for the public data release<sup><span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fn1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fn1\" data-open=\"fn1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-fn js-xref-fn\">1</a></sup> and imaging, the visibility data were averaged to 16\u00a0MHz\u00a0channel<sup>\u22121</sup> and 20\u00a0s, which is sufficient to image a field of view of around 0.75\u00a0\u00d7\u00a00.75\u00a0arcsec. In total, 24\u2009903 sources from FIRST have been observed as part of the mJIVE-20 survey, with 4965 sources detected on mas-scales above a signal-to-noise ratio of 6.75\u03c3.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Although the field of view of the averaged data sets is sufficient to find galaxy-scale gravitational lenses (the average image separation of the CLASS lens sample is around 1.2 arcsec; Browne et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), radio-loud-lensed objects have been found with image separations as large as 4.6 arcsec within CLASS (McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>). Note that a search for wide-separation gravitational lens systems (6 \u2264 \u03b8<sub>sep</sub> \u2264 15\u00a0arcsec) in the CLASS data returned a null result (Phillips et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; McKean <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This is because such wide-separation images require massive lenses and the lensing optical depth of galaxy groups and clusters is over an order of magnitude less than for galaxies. Therefore, we retrieved the un-averaged mJIVE-20 survey <em>uv</em>-data and re-mapped each pointing to make a wide-field image that was 3.5\u00a0\u00d7\u00a03.5\u00a0arcsec in size. We then ran the mJIVE-20 object detection software on the re-imaged data (note that it is these data that are now available in catalogue form from the mJIVE-20 survey archive).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To identify lens candidates in the wide-field catalogue available on 2013 June 30, sources were selected when there was the detection of at least two radio components at the &gt;6.75\u03c3 level, with a separation &gt;100\u00a0mas and with an integrated flux ratio &lt;15:1. Given the resolution of our data (the average synthetized beam is about 11\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05\u00a0mas<sup>2</sup>), we could in principle separate components on 5\u201320 mas-scales. However, this would have severely increased the contamination from core-jet sources and we also do not expect image separations on this scale from galaxy-sized gravitational lenses. The lower size limit that we selected is about three\u00a0times smaller than the smallest separation lens known (i.e. \u03b8<sub>sep</sub>\u00a0= 334\u00a0mas; Wucknitz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2004</a>), but this small size was chosen to ensure that the merging pair from any potential four image gravitational lens system, which are highly magnified with respect to the counter images, would be identified. We chose a less stringent flux-ratio between the components than CLASS as we were also interested in finding asymmetric lens systems, which are useful for studying the inner parts of lensing galaxies. Using these criteria, we identified 81 radio sources that are then manually classified with grades from A to D, where grade A corresponds to the highest possibility to be a gravitational lensing system. By visually inspecting and/or remapping these sources and by cross-correlating with optical imaging and spectroscopy from the SDSS, we remove those sources with a clear core-jet morphology or that are mis-identified residual side lobes in our catalogue.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">From this process, we obtain a sample of 14 good gravitational lens candidates with grades A and B that have multiple compact components with a similar surface brightness and, therefore, are not likely to be simply core-jet type radio sources. Interestingly, we find that two of the class A candidates (MJV02639 and MJV03238) are already confirmed as gravitational lenses by CLASS (B1127+385 and B2319+051; Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Rusin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Neither the calibrator list nor the FIRST sub-sample used for mJIVE-20 was selected to specifically include (or exclude) gravitationally lensed radio sources that were found by CLASS; we note that neither of the two detected CLASS lenses are VLBA calibrators. This already demonstrates that wide-field VLBI observations can be used to identify radio-loud lensed sources. To determine the lensing nature of the remaining 12 candidates, we follow a similar strategy to CLASS by observing the sources at a higher angular resolution (to test the conservation of surface brightness) and at different frequencies (to test whether the radio-spectra are identical). If a lens candidate does have a radio spectrum and surface brightness consistent with gravitational lensing, we then test whether the high-resolution structure of the images is consistent with a plausible lensing mass model. For example, the two known lensed sources, MJV02639 and MJV03238, have been previously observed with VLBI instruments between 1.7 and 15\u00a0GHz (Koopmans et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1999</a>; Rusin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>). Therefore, we can use already-obtained information on what the follow-up of these systems would reveal. The lensed images in these two cases show nearly identical surface brightness and radio spectra. Moreover, the flux density ratio of the two lensed images does not show any dependency on the frequency. The high frequency imaging resolves the lensed images of both the sources into multiple sub-components, which can be fit by a simple lens mass model. Consequently, they would have passed all of the selection criteria based on the radio imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The follow-up observations are discussed in the next section and all these steps for selecting and confirming the lens candidates are summarized in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The 1.4\u00a0GHz imaging from the mJIVE-20 observations of the twelve best lens candidates and the two confirmed gravitationally lensed radio sources are presented in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, respectively. The maximum image separation of the candidate lensed images, as compared to those from the CLASS survey, is shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"127267412\" The blue scale bar in each image represents 0.2 arcsec.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189fig2a.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=JMI-NCP3Nn3w~ReGRkFuWnZX~VUAEHcF1JWIqc8dlIvzT1tdWjQyHUo-Me-6-aHrAQCFCgeXCN43uOcU-M5GR73yx4Vh-BZ6fpq8YRF~WOe0dUL5X~4ghrD7aKASc-dz9IH4KJKo7XA6P-Zrz8xhhAsocljnzgknANJIEzEi5FmoPLdqUMwnJJltFdgQBgjhi6f7DFJtetvTQ2G6IT2Aoy6-SSdR1UKq3rjaTEOxCKrozpjcXCyH-0gt-vvFHBuuQri~9zSgRpJtNDnHCJ2Rl9VFiNC7w3E9Xpjyx2rZdu0IyKMc73udG6HKL22omqG2W0AcAZ7Inhn0a3uZt0IvkQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The cleaned images at 1.4\u00a0GHz of the twelve lens candidates from the mJIVE-20 survey observations. Contours are at (\u22123, 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 27)\u00a0\u00d7 \u03c3rms, the off-source rms noise. The beam size is shown in the bottom left corner, which is on average 11\u00a0\u00d7\u00a05 mas2; north is up and east is left. The blue scale bar in each image represents 0.2 arcsec.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig2a.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/127267413/sty3189fig2a.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig2a.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"127267413\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/sty3189fig2a.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=ZFnLMpIU5jf3UTPUB4ToxcAVZvj3Mm0JfDRsp-2Y6mbn2rJDrxB1OVp-FPicEZcSnxvI~BqEc2x9Fe3~Bv96tOa5Op62oa0aRKx0t0nPJBRlKzz6vk01-9qiAprMkFPoT2~UV5XjSa4BYU1zFsLYmXbzvRc-UdKU7AKdnThJh-G~J57eZc7Ay-jM5HoO2XEmrvZhu05SG0gLl~LYT6YP9-b0vOnF11WYELi-Z7O64dHBNesCWjXJqj4Z0J0Kq0ALriJwRUhQ7eQKEkxPXO7jKlk5prOtMGDVlJUzN1dQSjWYxJjuPjl9tG4PwjI8mR0y6Pakoet9rtjD50JumRXwpA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&amp;sec=127267413&amp;ar=5211079&amp;xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&amp;imagename=&amp;siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig2a.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/m_sty3189fig2b.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&amp;Signature=lE2bu1WvalYx410IyUk8axDFohk53TfsFlNZgAhZVOovHcxrO~Ns8PiVGD4aKksvia3JORKl7TfNVMPu0cvGPuVa1l96EBioE7CNK5FN7uyDVAg7Q9~S1Tly9Oh0M63lYLXS1pJGBZHhPMzaAm31gXyo6UMdSM04ccB~oDsi6Gm~zABm6qwv29q3FszhssOYG2KdfMK3n-WssMkXY76cfqCrMoqT51rsWeg1N8aQuSnSq50BXrvD21OLURj4ZzHkzbywcPn01Fjb~jUZ3avDiRCwvqW5BPL~X2oZhwWM-1vA5GmCwTCDvLzPmnJuB11WoZIioaD15L4QLbg5JAU-CA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"The cleaned images at 1.4\u00a0GHz of the twelve lens candidates from the mJIVE-20 survey observations. The bins are 0.5 arcsec wide.\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig4.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/127267415/sty3189fig4.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig4.jpg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"127267415\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/483/2/10.1093_mnras_sty3189/2/sty3189fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611465521&Signature=W~se48Cw2EW5WwhIbFtYoswDh86zG8eyJ1N60oe-C-vdXpvxijtMdt3FbcJHnKR8lZ~Mh8FWpk8fR-VsJjgKTFG9fSE3fUCoqe9Hr-klvwWhoNVVwGY3KdpWlNOElOhR9CCSmikl1QI8IVhYasOH-UnlxXVrjqr8u3WrhupxeyH82yQIc3cpwW~i~MGp4kNTlnmFosith4LFsbXvElmwlrh7APXMzu2FnS7SDVgbDQiJ3fKfkWJ22pwyg2k-uFekUWKDCl6Bh2wtArN~Lk-b16y~0buE9kpzjnKSfyZ60sB3Qjxhs0WfsvDPROnse-Xnvay94jR~dPVLk~v4HHY4kQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=127267415&ar=5211079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig4.jpg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A comparison between the maximum image separation of the mJIVE-20 gravitational lens candidates (red) and the CLASS gravitational lenses (blue). The bins are 0.5 arcsec wide.</p></div></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267416 id=\"127267416\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>3 FOLLOW-UP OBSERVATIONS\u00a0AND DATA REDUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We followed up the 12 remaining lens candidates with the VLBA at <em>C</em> band between 2013 November and 2014 April (Project IDs: BM397 and BM398; PI: McKean). This upgraded wide-band receiver allows observations to be carried out between 4 and 8\u00a0GHz, with two separate spectral windows that can be separated over the band to provide simultaneous multifrequency imaging. We selected central observing frequencies of 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, based on the advice of National Radio Astronomy Observatory (NRAO) staff. The bandwidth of each spectral window was 128\u00a0MHz through dual polarization at each frequency, and the data were recorded at 2048\u00a0Mbit\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Given the increase in the observing frequency and the resulting decrease in the primary beam size (6\u201311 arcmin), we could no longer use in-beam calibration, and so, we switched between the target and the phase-reference source every 5 min, with \u223c3\u00a0min scans on source and \u223c1\u00a0min scans on the calibrator. The observations were typically \u223c1.5\u00a0h in total for each lens candidate. The rms map noise of the naturally weighted images was typically between 40 and 70\u00a0\u03bcJy\u00a0beam<sup>\u22121</sup> at both frequencies, where the upper noise values were due to the difficulty in modelling diffuse structure in those cases that were only detected with the shortest baselines of the VLBA. Such cases resulted in a residual fringe pattern in the images, which also helped us establish if a candidate lensed image was extended or not. A summary of the observations is given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Two examples of the <em>uv</em>-coverage are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a> for a low- and high-declination candidate at the two observing frequencies.</p>                        <a id=\"127267418\" scrollto-destination=\"127267418\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img alt=\"Examples of the uv-coverage for the highest (left) and lowest declination (right) lens candidates at 4.1 (orange points) and 7.1\u00a0GHz (blue points).\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig5.jpg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/127267418/sty3189fig5.jpg\" data-path-from-xml=\"sty3189fig5.jpg\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">A summary of the 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz follow-up observations of the mJIVE-20 lens candidates with the VLBA and the rejection criteria. The columns (from left to right) give the mJIVE-20 identification number, the VLBA observation date, the lens confidence category (A or B), the rejection criteria, and whether there is an optical ID in Pan-STARRS. The rejection criteria are based on the spectral index and the surface brightness of the individual candidate lensed images, and whether a simple lens mass model can explain the structure (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>). The symbol\u00a0\u00d7 is used when a criterion for being gravitationally lensed has not been fulfilled.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>mJIVE-20 ID<span 23\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>Yes\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV06997\u00a0</td><td>2013 Nov 15\u00a0</td><td>A\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV07382\u00a0</td><td>2014 Mar 11\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV07417\u00a0</td><td>2014 Mar 29\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV07467\u00a0</td><td>2014 Mar 05\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV11715\u00a0</td><td>2014 Apr 24\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV11797\u00a0</td><td>2014 Apr 19\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV14607\u00a0</td><td>2014 Mar 02\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>MJV16999\u00a0</td><td>2013 Dec 07\u00a0</td><td>A\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u00d7\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>No\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/127267419\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">We apply the standard VLBA calibration procedure for phase-referenced observations using the Astronomical Image Processing System (<span class=\"small-caps\">aips</span>). We start by applying the Earth orientation and ionospheric corrections. After an initial flagging of bad data, we apply the a priori amplitude calibration by using the gain curves and system temperatures of the individual antennas, and correcting for the sampler offsets. Next, we correct for the instrumental delay and parallactic angle variation. We then perform global fringe fitting to correct for the residual fringe delays and rates, which are measured from observations of the phase-reference calibrator using solution intervals of between 3 and 5\u00a0min. We use the fringe-finder calibrator to perform the bandpass calibration and we split out the data at the two frequencies separately in order to perform the imaging. Most of the targets are detected at a relatively low significance (3\u201310\u03c3), therefore when attempting phase-only self-calibration more than 60\u00a0per\u2009cent of the solutions failed, even when a solution interval much longer than the coherence time was used. For this reason, we do not perform self-calibration. We <span class=\"small-caps\">clean</span> the images by using a threshold that is three times the theoretical rms noise level and a natural weighting scheme. We assume a conservative uncertainty of \u223c10\u00a0per\u2009cent on the estimate of the absolute flux density, which takes into account calibration errors and possible variability in the candidate lensed images when we consider the relative flux ratios.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=127267421 id=\"127267421\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>4 RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now summarize the results of our lens search. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-1\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-1\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.1</a>, we describe the properties of the remaining 12 lens candidates at all frequencies. We also give a discussion on whether they meet the gravitational lensing criteria or not, as illustrated in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1\" data-open=\"fig1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>, which is summarized in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. In Section\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-sec4-2\"></span><a href=\"#sec4-2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">4.2</a>, we present lens mass models for those candidates that pass the VLBA imaging tests. In the Appendix, we show the maps from the 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz VLBA observations in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>\u2013<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa13\" data-open=\"figa13\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A13</a>, the radio spectral energy distributions and flux ratios as a function of frequency are shown in Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>, respectively, and we show the optical imaging of the candidates from Pan-STARRS in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>. Also, a summary of the properties of the 14 targets from our lens search is presented in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>. We would like to highlight that the large negative spectral indices derived by our measurements must be taken with caution. This is because the spectral index can be biased towards more negative values by angular resolution and surface brightness sensitivity effects, especially when the images are very resolved at high frequencies. This does not affect our ability to discriminate between lensed and non-lensed sources, as we use the spectral indices as just an indication for comparing the spectral energy distribution of the two putative lensed images.</p>                        <a id=\"127267423\" scrollto-destination=\"127267423\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed properties of the final sample of 14 lens candidates. Column 1: mJIVE-20 ID of the lens candidate. Column 2: name of the components. Columns 3 and 4: right ascension and declination of the component. Column 5: flux density from the FIRST survey at 1.4\u00a0GHz. The uncertainty on this flux density is around 5\u00a0per\u2009cent. Column 6: flux density from the GB6 survey at 4.85\u00a0GHz. Column 7: flux density from VLBA 1.4\u00a0GHz observations. Column 8: flux density from VLBA 4.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 9: flux density from VLBA 7.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 10: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 11: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz. Column 12: surface brightness at 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 13: surface brightness at 7.1\u00a0GHz.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>mJIVE-20 ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n        </a></div></div></div><div class=\"table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl2\" data-id=\"tbl2\"><span class=\"label\">Table 2.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observed properties of the final sample of 14 lens candidates. Column 1: mJIVE-20 ID of the lens candidate. Column 2: name of the components. Columns 3 and 4: right ascension and declination of the component. Column 5: flux density from the FIRST survey at 1.4\u00a0GHz. The uncertainty on this flux density is around 5\u00a0per\u2009cent. Column 6: flux density from the GB6 survey at 4.85\u00a0GHz. Column 7: flux density from VLBA 1.4\u00a0GHz observations. Column 8: flux density from VLBA 4.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 9: flux density from VLBA 7.1\u00a0GHz observations. The 3\u03c3 detection limit is estimated as three times the rms noise within the same area of the 1.4\u00a0GHz detection of that image. Column 10: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 11: power-law spectral index \u03b1 between 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz. Column 12: surface brightness at 4.1\u00a0GHz. Column 13: surface brightness at 7.1\u00a0GHz.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>mJIVE-20 ID<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Component<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>RA<span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>S</em><sub>GB6</sub><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$S_{1.4~\\rm {GHz}}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$S_{4.1~\\rm {GHz}}$|</span><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$S_{7.1~\\rm {GHz}}$|</span><span ><td>23:21:40.801\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0+\u00a005:27:37.225\u00a0</td><td>82.3\u00a0</td><td>76\u00a0\u00b1\u00a08\u00a0</td><td>63\u00a0\u00b1\u00a06\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>\u00a0</td><td>B\u00a0</td><td>23:21:40.808\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0+\u00a005:27:36.466\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>19\u00a0\u00b1\u00a02\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0\u2013\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td><td>\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/127267423\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=127267424 id=\"127267424\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>4.1 Description of the individual lens candidates</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We now give a brief review of the radio and optical data for our lens candidates. In each case, we denote the candidate lensed image with the highest flux density at 1.4\u00a0GHz as component A, and the second and third highest as components B and C, respectively.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267426 id=\"127267426\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-1>4.1.1 MJV00019</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens candidate shows two components separated by 537 mas at 1.4\u00a0GHz (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Component A has extended structure in the east\u2013west direction with a curved morphology, while component B is also resolved, but has a smaller angular-extent than component A. Therefore, their surface brightness agrees with gravitational lensing. At 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, the two components are detected and resolved into multiple sub-components and their surface brightnesses are consistent (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa1\" data-open=\"figa1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A1</a>). The spectral indices of components A and B between 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz are comparable within the uncertainties and it is steep (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$\\alpha _{4.1}^{7.1} \\sim -1.9$|\u2060</span>; see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>). For these reasons, MJV00019 passes the observational tests and remains a lens candidate. However, we note that 55\u00a0per\u2009cent of the FIRST emission was not recovered on VLBI-scales, which suggests there is a significant undetected component of extended emission associated with this source. Due to its steep spectrum between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz, and low flux density at 5\u00a0GHz, this object was not selected to be observed during CLASS. No optical emission from a putative lensing galaxy or the candidate lensed images is detected at the location of the system (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267428 id=\"127267428\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-2>4.1.2 MJV00533</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MJV00533 has two resolved radio components separated by 248 mas at 1.4\u00a0GHz, where each component shows evidence for an extension in the east\u2013west direction (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). At 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, component A is unresolved and there is no detection of the sub-component to the west, while component B shows faint resolved extended structure at 4.1\u00a0GHz and is completely resolved out at 7.1\u00a0GHz (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa2\" data-open=\"figa2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A2</a>). Therefore, the surface brightness of the candidate lensed images is not conserved between the two frequencies (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). We note that their spectral indices are similar between 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz (see Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>), which highlights the importance of the higher-frequency data in determining the status of such lens candidates. The surface brightness and morphology of this system suggest that it is a core-jet (or core-hotspot) source. There is no evidence for an optical counterpart for this object (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267430 id=\"127267430\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-3>4.1.3 MJV02990</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At 1.4\u00a0GHz, this lens candidate consists of two resolved components that are separated by 240\u00a0mas (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>), where component A also has the larger angular size, respecting the surface brightness criterion for being a lens system. At 4.1\u00a0GHz, component A is detected and found to be unresolved, while component B is not detected (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa3\" data-open=\"figa3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A3</a>). Given the flux ratio between components A and B at 1.4\u00a0GHz, the fainter component should have been detected at the 7.5\u03c3 level at 4.1\u00a0GHz, if it was also unresolved (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>; and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>). Neither component is detected at 7.1\u00a0GHz. Overall, the multifrequency radio data suggests that MJV02990 is not a gravitational lens system, but is more likely a core-jet, mainly due to component B being undetected at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, which implies that the surface brightness is not conserved. There is no detection of optical emission at the location of the two radio components (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267432 id=\"127267432\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-4>4.1.4 MJV04363</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MJV04363 has two radio components separated by 791 mas at 1.4\u00a0GHz, with component A being slightly resolved in the east\u2013west direction, whereas component B is found to be unresolved (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). At 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, a third unresolved component (C) is detected between the two candidate lensed images (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa4\" data-open=\"figa4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A4</a>). This third radio image is closer in projection to component A and it could be the emission from a possible lensing galaxy, as for example in the lensing systems CLASS B2045+265, CLASS B2108+213, and CLASS B2114\u00a0+\u00a0022 (Augusto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; McKean et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007b</a>). If this were the case, then the position of component C suggests that the potential lensing galaxy should be highly elliptical to reproduce the observed image configuration. However, the spectral energy distribution of the two putative lensed images is significantly different, indicating that they are not gravitationally lensed images of the same background object (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>). Therefore, the surface brightness and spectral energy distribution of the components suggest that this system more likely has an optically thick radio core (component C) with two jets or hotspots (components A and B). Also, only 7\u00a0per\u2009cent of the FIRST emission is detected by the mJIVE-20 observations. Finally, there is faint optical emission at the location of this source in both Pan-STARSS and SDSS (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>; Abazajian et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Flewelling et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2016</a>). The optical emission is classified as a galaxy, with a magnitude in the <em>r</em> band of 21.95; there is no spectroscopic information available, so the redshift is unknown.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267434 id=\"127267434\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-5>4.1.5 MJV06997</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This candidate shows two resolved components separated by 276 mas at 1.4\u00a0GHz (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). However, we detect only the fainter component B at both 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, and at these frequencies, it is unresolved (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa5\" data-open=\"figa5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A5</a>). Moreover, given the flux ratio between the two components at 1.4\u00a0GHz, component A should have been detected at the 22\u03c3 level at 4.1\u00a0GHz (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>). The images at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz also show a strong fringe pattern passing through the non-detected component A. This indicates that emission is detected at this position on the shortest baselines, but not on the majority of the VLBA baselines, where it is resolved out. Therefore, based on the spectral energy distribution and the surface brightness of the components, this candidate is ruled out as a gravitationally lensed radio source. We conclude that this system is likely a core-jet source, where the jet (component A) has a higher flux-density at lower frequencies than the flat-spectrum radio core (component B). There is no optical emission detected at the position of the two radio components (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267436 id=\"127267436\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-6>4.1.6 MJV07382</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">MJV07382 is one of the most interesting lens candidates that was selected from the mJIVE\u201320 parent catalogue. The object is comprised of two extended objects around 30\u00a0mas in size that are separated by 221\u00a0mas at 1.4\u00a0GHz (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The morphology and small separation between the components suggested that it may be a quadruply imaged radio source, where the mJIVE-20 observations detected only the highly magnified merging pair. The additional 1.4\u00a0GHz imaging taken as part of the mJIVE-20 programme failed to detect any counter-image emission down to a flux-ratio limit of &gt;27 (for a 5\u03c3 detection), which should have been sufficient if this is a quadruply imaged radio source. At 4.1\u00a0GHz, we detect only component A, but there is a strong side-lobe pattern corresponding to component B, indicating that there is resolved extended structure associated with this component (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa6\" data-open=\"figa6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A6</a>). We do not detect either component at 7.1\u00a0GHz, but again, there is a fringe structure across the components at this frequency. In principle, given the flux density of component B at 1.4\u00a0GHz, it should have been detected at the 3.5\u03c3 level at 4.1\u00a0GHz, although the sparse <em>uv</em>-coverage may have affected the detectability (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>, and Figs\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa14\" data-open=\"figa14\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A14</a> and\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>). Given the differences in the surface brightness of the two components, MJV07382 is likely a core-jet object, where component A, with the highest surface brightness, being the core. There is no evidence for optical emission corresponding to this source in Pan-STARRS or SDSS (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267438 id=\"127267438\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-7>4.1.7 MJV07417</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At 1.4\u00a0GHz, this candidate shows a bright extended component A and an unresolved, marginally detected fainter component B that are separated by 458 mas (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). The map at 1.4\u00a0GHz also shows a strong fringe pattern associated with component A, which signifies that it is partly resolved out. There is no detection of either component in the 4.1 or 7.1\u00a0GHz observations (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa7\" data-open=\"figa7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A7</a>). Therefore, it is not possible to compare the spectral energy distributions of components A and B, or their surface brightness as a function of frequency. At 1.4\u00a0GHz, the surface brightness of components A and B are 44 and 21\u00a0Jy\u00a0arcsec<sup>\u22122</sup>, respectively. However, as component B is not resolved we do not have an accurate estimate of its surface brightness. There is extensive extended emission from this target that is not recovered by the 1.4\u00a0GHz VLBA imaging; the flux density measured by FIRST is almost seven times higher than the mJIVE-20 flux density. There is also no optical emission detected from this source (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>). Given the observational data in hand, we currently cannot exclude MJV07417 from our candidate list, even though it is unlikely to be a gravitational lensing system, given the extended nature of component A and the marginal detection of component B.</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267440 id=\"127267440\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-8>4.1.8 MJV07467</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This candidate has two components separated by 221 mas that are resolved at 1.4\u00a0GHz into two sub-components in a north\u2013south direction, and where almost all of the low-resolution FIRST emission is recovered on VLBI-scales by the mJIVE-20 observations (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> and Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). At 4.1\u00a0GHz, component A is resolved into two sub-components with a more east\u2013west morphology, while component B is marginally detected, showing a very diffuse and extended structure around a more compact central emission (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa8\" data-open=\"figa8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A8</a>). Therefore, the surface brightness is not conserved at 4.1\u00a0GHz, because the fainter image is also the most extended. At 7.1\u00a0GHz, only component A is detected, while component B is completely resolved out. Given the flux density ratio between the two components at 4.1\u00a0GHz (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa15\" data-open=\"figa15\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A15</a>), component B should have been detected at the 4\u03c3 level at 7.1\u00a0GHz if MJV07467 were a gravitationally lensed source. From the surface brightness and spectral energy distribution of the components, we reject this candidate as a gravitational lensing system. There is also no optical emission detected from this source (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>)</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267442 id=\"127267442\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-9>4.1.9 MJV11715</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">This lens candidate shows two components that are resolved in an east\u2013west direction at 1.4\u00a0GHz, and although they have a similar size, their flux densities differ by a factor of about 4 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). Since their morphology is consistent with gravitational lensing at 1.4\u00a0GHz, but their surface brightness is not, this candidate was followed up at 1.4\u00a0GHz with deeper observations as part of mJIVE-20. However, the size of the two components remained very similar, and so their surface brightness is not consistent with gravitational lensing (see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). These properties rule out this candidate as a lensed source. Moreover, at 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, only component A is detected, and this is resolved into three compact sub-components with a clear core-jet morphology (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa9\" data-open=\"figa9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A9</a>). There is no evidence of a residual fringe pattern in the images, which is a strong indication that component B is completely resolved out at these frequencies, confirming that the surface brightness between the two components is different. There is no optical counterpart of this object (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa16\" data-open=\"figa16\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A16</a>).</p>                    <h4 scrollto-destination=127267444 id=\"127267444\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1-10>4.1.10 MJV11797</h4>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">At 1.4\u00a0GHz, this lens candidate consists of two resolved components separated by 238 mas that are elongated in an east\u2013west direction (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>). When following them up at 4.1\u00a0GHz, we find that the two components are slightly resolved, also in the same direction as seen at 1.4\u00a0GHz. This morphology at both 1.4 and 4.1\u00a0GHz would be consistent with lensing, as seen on VLBI-scales in the gravitational lensing system JVAS\u00a0B0218+357 for example (Biggs et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>). At 7.1\u00a0GHz, we clearly detect component A, while component B is detected only at the 3\u03c3 level (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa10\" data-open=\"figa10\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A10</a>). However, there is a clear fringe pattern crossing through the location of component B, indicating that there is extended resolved structure associated with this component. For this reason, we smooth the 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz images to the same resolution as the 1.4\u00a0GHz data by using a <em>uv</em>-taper, in order to verify the marginal detection of component B (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-figa11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"figa11\" data-open=\"figa11\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">A11</a>). The surface brightness and morphology seem consistent with lensing, although component B is more resolved at 7.1\u00a0GHz. Also, the overall spectral energy distributions are similar, particularly at the highest frequencies, but the flux ratio changes from 1.4\u00a0GHz to 4.1 and 7.1\u00a0GHz, in that the flux density of component B is too high at 1.4\u00a0GHz.
